description: From Middle English ruyne, ruine, from Old French ruine, from Latin ruīna (“overthrow, ruin”), from ruō (“I fall down, tumble, sink in ruin, rush”).

entries.meaning: (countable, sometimes in the plural) The remains of a destroyed or dilapidated construction, such as a house or castle.
examples: The Veian and the Gabian towirs shall fall, / And one promiscuous ruin cover all; / Nor, after length of years, a stone betray / The place where once the very ruins lay.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The state of being a ruin, destroyed or decayed.
examples: The monastery has fallen into ruin.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Something that leads to serious trouble or destruction.
examples: Gambling has been the ruin of many.

entries.meaning: A change that destroys or defeats something; destruction; overthrow.
examples: the ruin of a ship or an army;  the ruin of a constitution or a government;  the ruin of health or hopes

verbs.description: ruin (third-person singular simple present ruins, present participle ruining, simple past and past participle ruined or (dialectal, nonstandard) ruint)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause the fiscal ruin of; to bankrupt or drive out of business.
examples: With all these purchases, you surely mean to ruin us!

entries.meaning: To destroy or make something no longer usable.
examples: He ruined his new white slacks by accidentally spilling oil on them.

entries.meaning: To upset or overturn the plans or progress of, or to have a disastrous effect on something.
examples: My car breaking down just as I was on the road ruined my vacation.

entries.meaning: To make something less enjoyable or likeable.
examples: I used to love that song, but being assaulted when that song was playing ruined the song for me.

entries.meaning: To reveal the ending of (a story); to spoil.
(obsolete) To fall into a state of decay.
examples: Though he his house of polisht marble build, / Yet shall it ruine like the Moth's fraile cell

entries.meaning: (transitive, historical) To seduce or debauch, and thus harm the social standing of.
examples: The young libertine was notorious for ruining local girls.
